channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for NJ
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for NJ

item.title: Report X-2024090335
item.description:
Report X-2024090335

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-10T09:23:00+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-03
  • City: KEASBEY
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: UPON INSPECTION IF PACKAGE IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE hazardous materials certification DID NOT HAVE THE PACKAGE LISTED ON THE PAPERWORK. ALSO, THE PACKAGE WAS NOT SHIPPMENT USING HAZMAT SERVICE CODE FOR UN1689 Sodium cyanide, solid. THE SHIPPER WOULD NOT PICK UP THE PACKAGE FROM THE TERMINAL. THERE IS NO VISIBLE DAMAGE TO THE OUTER PACKAGING. FACILITY PROCEDURES FOR UNDAMAGED PACKAGE MISSING THE CORRECT HAZMAT DOCUMENTS AND AWAITING DISPOSTION FROM PGH.

item.title: Report E-2024090068
item.description:
Report E-2024090068

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-08T09:12:56+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-01
  • City: NEWARK
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO CNW, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: It was reported that approximately 1 ounce of BCL Aqua Clearreleased from a 20-gallon plastic drum due to improper packaging. The release impacted the top of the drum at the cap at dock door 36. No storm drains or waterways were reported to be impacted by the release. ERTS dispatched a contractor to the site to complete cleanup activities. Upon the contractorâ€™s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted the top of the drum and estimated that one (1) ounce of material was released due to a defective cap. The Contractors overpacked the drum into a 55-gallon vented polymer and staged the drum onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization

item.title: Report E-2024090034
item.description:
Report E-2024090034

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-05T09:13:49+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-22
  • City: BURLINGTON TOWNSHIP
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On August 22, 2o24, two (2) boxes containing five (5) 1-gallon jugs of UN3149 were damaged by a forklift and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the truck floor and loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and a neutralizing agent to remediate the UN3149-impacted dock floor and box truck. All impacted material was collected and containerized into four (4) 55-gallon drums for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024090039
item.description:
Report E-2024090039

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-05T09:13:49+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-01
  • City: NEWARK
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 3500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics Terminal XNJ experienced a UN1789 Transchem Muriatic Acid release from multiple boxes each containing (2) 1-gallon poly jugs. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct onsite cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 6-oiunces of product released to the pallet of cardboard boxes on the dock only. The release was suspected to occur due to heat and expansion of the material in the bottles as the caps on the jugs were leaking. The impacted cardboard and faulty jugs were collected into (5) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.
